mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn14.11:1.4.pli: Ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
sn14.11:1.4.en: The element of light, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

sn14.11:3.1.pli: “Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, ābhādhātu—ayaṁ dhātu andhakāraṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.1.en: “Mendicant, the element of light appears due to the element of darkness.

sn14.11:3.2.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, subhadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu asubhaṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.2.en: The element of beauty appears due to the element of ugliness.

sn14.11:3.3.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu rūpaṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.3.en: The element of the dimension of infinite space appears due to the element of form.

sn14.11:3.4.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.4.en: The element of the dimension of infinite consciousness appears due to the element of the dimension of infinite space.

sn14.11:3.5.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.5.en: The element of the dimension of nothingness appears due to the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn14.11:3.6.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ paṭicca paññāyati.
sn14.11:3.6.en: The element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception appears due to the element of the dimension of nothingness.

sn14.11:3.7.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu nirodhaṁ paṭicca paññāyatī”ti.
sn14.11:3.7.en: The element of the cessation of perception and feeling appears due to the element of cessation.”

sn14.11:5.2.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu saṅkhārāvasesasamāpatti pattabbā.
sn14.11:5.2.en: The element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception is an attainment with only a residue of conditioned phenomena.

sn14.11:5.3.pli: Yāyaṁ, bhikkhu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—ayaṁ dhātu nirodhasamāpatti pattabbā”ti.
sn14.11:5.3.en: The element of the cessation of perception and feeling is an attainment of cessation.”

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 14.11
Chapter Two
Seven Elements

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn14.12:2.2.pli: Kāmadhātuṁ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati kāmasaññā, kāmasaññaṁ paṭicca uppajjati kāmasaṅkappo, kāmasaṅkappaṁ paṭicca uppajjati kāmacchando, kāmacchandaṁ paṭicca uppajjati kāmapariḷāho, kāmapariḷāhaṁ paṭicca uppajjati kāmapariyesanā.
sn14.12:2.2.en: The element of sensuality gives rise to sensual perceptions. Sensual perceptions give rise to sensual thoughts. Sensual thoughts give rise to sensual desires. Sensual desires give rise to sensual passions. Sensual passions give rise to searches for sensual pleasures.

sn14.12:3.1.pli: Byāpādadhātuṁ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaññā, byāpādasaññaṁ paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaṅkappo …pe… byāpādacchando … byāpādapariḷāho … byāpādapariyesanā …
sn14.12:3.1.en: The element of malice gives rise to malicious perceptions. Malicious perceptions give rise to malicious thoughts. … malicious desires … malicious passions … malicious searches …

sn14.12:4.1.pli: Vihiṁsādhātuṁ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati vihiṁsāsaññā; vihiṁsāsaññaṁ paṭicca uppajjati vihiṁsāsaṅkappo …pe… vihiṁsāchando … vihiṁsāpariḷāho … vihiṁsāpariyesanā …
sn14.12:4.1.en: The element of cruelty gives rise to cruel perceptions. Cruel perceptions give rise to cruel thoughts. … cruel desires … cruel passions … cruel searches …

sn14.12:7.2.en: The element of renunciation gives rise to perceptions of renunciation.

sn14.12:8.1.en: The element of good will gives rise to perceptions of good will.

sn14.12:9.1.en: The element of harmlessness gives rise to perceptions of harmlessness.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 14.12
Chapter Two
With a Cause

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

iti44:2.3.pli: Saupādisesā ca nibbānadhātu, anupādisesā ca nibbānadhātu.
iti44:2.3.en: The element of extinguishment with residue, and the element of extinguishment with no residue.

iti44:3.1.en: And what is the element of extinguishment with residue?

iti44:3.5.en: is called the element of extinguishment with residue.

iti44:4.1.en: And what is the element of extinguishment with no residue?

iti44:4.4.en: This is called the element of extinguishment with no residue.

mlDocs.title:
So It Was Said 44
The Book of the Twos
Chapter Two
Elements of Extinguishment

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

dn16:3.20.1.pli: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, tadāyaṁ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.20.1.en: Furthermore, when the Realized One becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.

dn16:4.38.2.pli: Yañca, ānanda, rattiṁ tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṁ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati.
dn16:4.38.2.en: The night when a Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening; and the night he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.

dn16:4.42.10.pli: Yañca piṇḍapātaṁ paribhuñjitvā tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca piṇḍapātaṁ paribhuñjitvā tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati.
dn16:4.42.10.en: The almsmeal after eating which a Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening; and the almsmeal after eating which he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.

dn16:5.8.6.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’ti, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṁ saṁvejanīyaṁ ṭhānaṁ.
dn16:5.8.6.en: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’—that is an inspiring place.

dn16:5.8.9.pli: ‘idha tathāgato jāto’tipi, ‘idha tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambuddho’tipi, ‘idha tathāgatena anuttaraṁ dhammacakkaṁ pavattitan’tipi, ‘idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’tipi.
dn16:5.8.9.en: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’ and ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’ and ‘Here the supreme Wheel of Dhamma was rolled forth by the Realized One!’ and ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’

mlDocs.title:
Long Discourses 16
The Great Discourse on the Buddha’s Extinguishment

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an6.38:2.1.pli: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, brāhmaṇa, atthi ārabbhadhātū”ti?
an6.38:2.1.en: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of initiative?”

an6.38:2.5.pli: “Yaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, ārabbhadhātuyā sati ārabbhavanto sattā paññāyanti, ayaṁ sattānaṁ attakāro ayaṁ parakāro.
an6.38:2.5.en: “Since there is an element of initiative, and sentient beings who initiate activity are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.

an6.38:3.1.pli: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, brāhmaṇa, atthi nikkamadhātu …pe…
an6.38:3.1.en: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of persistence …

an6.38:3.9.pli: “Yaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, upakkamadhātuyā sati upakkamavanto sattā paññāyanti, ayaṁ sattānaṁ attakāro ayaṁ parakāro.
an6.38:3.9.en: “Since there is an element of energy, and sentient beings who have energy are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.38
4. Deities
One’s Own Volition

an4.118:1.6.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’ti, bhikkhave, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṁ saṁvejanīyaṁ ṭhānaṁ.
an4.118:1.6.en: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment, with no residue!’—that is an inspiring place.

an6.111:1.7.pli: Kāmadhātuyā pahānāya nekkhammadhātu bhāvetabbā, byāpādadhātuyā pahānāya abyāpādadhātu bhāvetabbā, vihiṁsādhātuyā pahānāya avihiṁsādhātu bhāvetabbā.
an6.111:1.7.en: You should develop the element of renunciation to give up the element of sensuality, the element of good will to give up the element of malice, and the element of harmlessness to give up the element of cruelty.

sn45.7:2.4.en: “Mendicant, the removal of greed, hate, and delusion is a term for the element of extinguishment.

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an6.41:2.10.pli: Atthi, āvuso, amumhi dārukkhandhe asubhadhātu, yaṁ nissāya bhikkhu iddhimā cetovasippatto amuṁ dārukkhandhaṁ asubhantveva adhimucceyyā”ti.
an6.41:2.10.en: Because the element of ugliness exists in the tree trunk. Relying on that a mendicant with psychic powers could determine it to be nothing but ugly.”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.41
4. Deities
A Tree Trunk

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato
mlDocs.title:
So It Was Said 51
The Book of the Threes
Chapter One
Elements

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn14.13:3.1.pli: “Mahati kho esā, kaccāna, dhātu yadidaṁ avijjādhātu.
sn14.13:3.1.en: “It’s a mighty thing, Kaccāna, the element of ignorance.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 14.13
Chapter Two
In the Brick Hall

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn22.47:2.4.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, mano, atthi dhammā, atthi avijjādhātu.
sn22.47:2.4.en: The mind, ideas, and the element of ignorance are all present.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 22.47
5. Be Your Own Island
Ways of Regarding

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an4.23:3.1.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, rattiṁ tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati yañca rattiṁ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṁ etasmiṁ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati sabbaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti, no aññathā.
an4.23:3.1.en: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 4.23
3. At Uruvelā
The World

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

iti112:4.1.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, rattiṁ tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṁ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṁ etasmiṁ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati, sabbaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti no aññathā,
iti112:4.1.en: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

mlDocs.title:
So It Was Said 112
The Book of the Fours
The Chapter on the Brahmin’s Offering of the Teaching
The World

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an8.19:15.2.pli: evamevaṁ kho, pahārāda, bahū cepi bhikkhū anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyanti, na tena nibbānadhātuyā ūnattaṁ vā pūrattaṁ vā paññāyati.
an8.19:15.2.en: In the same way, though several mendicants become fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the element of extinguishment never empties or fills up.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 8.19
2. The Great Chapter
With Pahārāda

an8.70:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, tadāyaṁ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
an8.70:21.1.en: Furthermore, when the Realized One becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.

ud8.5:20.6.pli: Yañca piṇḍapātaṁ paribhuñjitvā tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca piṇḍapātaṁ paribhuñjitvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati.
ud8.5:20.6.en: The almsmeal after eating which a Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening; and the almsmeal after eating which he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.

ud5.5:23.2.pli: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bahū cepi bhikkhū anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyanti, na tena nibbānadhātuyā ūnattaṁ vā pūrattaṁ vā paññāyati.
ud5.5:23.2.en: In the same way, though several mendicants become fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the element of extinguishment never empties or fills up.

dn29:29.3.pli: Yañca, cunda, rattiṁ tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṁ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṁ etasmiṁ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati. Sabbaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti no aññathā,
dn29:29.3.en: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.
